journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Mathematical and experimental study on flow of wood plastic composite to acquire its constitutive equation

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Golzar, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tarbiat Modares University, PO Box 14115-111, Tehran, Iran Email: m.golzar@modares.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents a study on the rheological behavior of wood plastic composites with a mathematical approach to acquire their melt constitutive equation. The wood plastic composites were produced with four compositions of high density polyethylene as the matrix and very fine wood particles, smaller than 50 µm in size, as the fillers: 40, 50, 60 and 70 wt% of wood content. Storage modulus (G′), loss modulus (G′′), complex viscosity (η*) were measured for all four composites at a temperature of 170°C and for shear rates in the range of 1–500 rad/s. The results indicated a noticeable increase in all measured properties upon increasing the wood content. In mathematical approach, the main goal was to obtain the most fitted expression to relate shear stress with shear rate. Firstly power law model was applied considering a viscous behavior of the composites. In continue, generalized Maxwell model was used and the most fitted number of the elements in modeling was analyzed for various wood contents. Moreover, Cox–Merz rule was evaluated for the composites, where it showed that this rule is only valid for the composites in some special conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A wide range of composites containing different polymeric materials, with wood fillers are known as wood plastic composites (WPC). This new composite has expanded the concept of wood products from its traditional meaning such as particle board and medium density fiber board (MDF) into a new category of products having superior performances.1 While, since 90 years ago, wood fibers have been used in plastics to make new composites, it was not until recent decades that special attention have been attracted to these new materials.2

Adding wood particles to plastics affects the properties such as stiffening the products with a reduced toughness. It also decreases its thermal expansion which results in less shrinkage and warpage.3 Most of research works on WPCs have been carried out on mechanical properties such as tensile strength, impact strength, modulus of elasticity (MOE) and modulus of resilience (MOR).4–6

There are many factors such as polymer-type, volume fraction, size and shape of fillers, interaction between the polymeric matrix and filler particles that affect the mechanical and rheological properties of the final product.7

Optimizing the process condition of WPCs for the purpose of reducing production cost is one of the major challenges in this industry. In commercial products, WPCs are produced with relatively high contents of wood, e.g. about 50 and 60 wt%, which is close to its maximum packing content.8 Such volume fractions are much higher than those of inorganic fillers. The main reason is the lower cost of wood that provides the capacity to formulate the composite with higher filler content at a lower cost of final product.9
WPCs are mostly produced via an extrusion process. As the material is in melt state, proper knowledge of their flow behavior is required especially when they are highly filled.

A review of literatures shows that the reported rheology studies on the highly filled WPCs are rare. The current works have aimed at understanding the influence of fillers on the composite flow properties. Due to the low contents of wood in the studied composites, little basis is provided for applying their data into commercial process of WPC.8 There is no clear theoretical basis for the melt flow behavior of WPCs.

As there is possibility of using various components in WPCs, such as various polymer types and grades and especially various types of woods (species and sizes) and also additives, there is a wide area for research and development, both scientifically and industrially. For this reason, extensive works have been carried out to report the effect of wood component on the final properties of WPC.4–6,10,11 On the other hand, usage of recycled material in WPC is a bonus for WPC processors. Fine wood particles, produced by sanding process (a process stage in particle board manufacturing process), is a very attractive and promising source as wood component. However, these fine wood particles will impose challenging conditions in terms of processability.

This study is in continue of the previous works conducted by the authors aimed to investigate the rheological behavior of the WPCs.12 In the way of modeling and analyzing the WPC flow behaviors; there is a need to measure shear stress versus shear rate. It is not possible to examine this composite under the unidirectional shear condition (due to melt breakage or slip) to directly attain the required results. Thus, one way to measure their rheological properties is to apply oscillatory shear condition. In the oscillatory shear experiments, the results are functions of frequency. In the first part of this research work, flow behaviors of the composites produced with the fine particles and HDPE as the polymeric matrix, have been investigated. In the second part, some proposed methods were evaluated and compared with each other. And in continue, the Cox–Merz rule and generalized Maxwell model were assessed for the composites.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
High density polyethylene (HDPE), grade I2, produced by Arak Petrochemical Co., Iran, was used as the polymeric material. Wood flour, with mesh size of 270, a byproduct of sanding process in a particle board manufacturing shop, was used as the wood component material. Table 1 gives some characteristics of the polymer matrix13 and Figure 1 shows a scanning electron microscopy image of the wood particles revealing the particle sizes (below 50 µm). No additive was used in the composites. Figure 1.
SEM micrograph of wood particles used in this study. Table 1.
Typical properties of HDPE, grade I213
Typical properties Test method (DIN) Unit Value
MFI at190°C, 5 kg 53,735 g/10 min 28
Density 53,479 g/mL 0.950
Notched impact strength 53,453 Mj/mm2 Min. 2.5
Standard yellow index 6167 – Max. 4
HDPE: high density polyethylene.

sec.title: Equipment
sec.p: A laboratory co-rotating twin-screw extruder was employed for compounding HDPE with wood flour in various wood contents (40–70 wt%). A perforated die was used to produce strands which then were chopped to granules. The barrel and die temperatures were set below 170°C to avoid wood burning. The screw rotational speed (r/min) was maintained at 10 rpm.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: The power law model for defining viscosity is one of the most famous and commonly used equations.14 In this work, power law equation was employed in three different views to model the flow behavior of the composites. The general equation for a power law is15 (1) where m is referred to as the consistency index and n the power law index. Therefore, the stress will be defined as (2)

sec.title: Method 1: Using the shear stress versus frequency
sec.p: According to the following equation, it is possible to calculate the shear rate form the frequency and shear strain.11 (3)
In this method, shear stress versus frequency can be simply changed into shear stress versus shear rate (τ(ω)→τ(γ·)).

sec.title: Method 2: Using complex viscosity versus frequency
sec.p: In this method, the Newtonian fluid equation was employed (as given in equation (4)11) and the complex viscosity (η*) was assumed to be equal to the viscosity of the composites. By this assumption the relation between the shear stress and shear rate can be proposed simply as equation (4). (4) (5)

sec.title: Method 3: Using dynamic viscosity versus frequency
sec.p: The basic assumption in this method is similar to Method 2, except that dynamic viscosity (η′) was used instead of complex viscosity in the Newton’s equation (equation (6)). The dynamic viscosity is obtained from the loss modulus according to equation (7).11 (6) (7)

One purpose of this study was to evaluate the validity of Cox–Merz rule for the WPCs made in this research work. This rule expresses a simple relation between complex viscosity and viscosity. It has been found by many researchers that this rule is valid for those polymeric materials with flexible molecules. Although there have been reports of its failure for some linear and branched polyethylene. The most important reason to use this rule is that obtaining |η*(ω)| over a wide range of frequencies is easier than obtaining η(γ·) over a wide range of shear rates in a cone and plate rheometer.11

The theory of linear viscoelasticity shows that if the relaxation modulus, G(t), is known, then the linear response to different types of deformation can be predicted. One of the most popular approaches is to use Maxwell model. Actual relaxation process can not be well described by a single element in Maxwell model. A high flexibility can be achieved using generalized Maxwell model. Giving adequate number of elements, generalized model can be fitted to any experimental data for G(t).11 As part of this study, the optimum number of elements in the Maxwell model and their initial shear modulus (G0) and relaxation time (λ) was determined for the composites.

sec.title: Cox–Merz rule
sec.p: As mentioned earlier, Cox–Merz rule relates viscosity and complex viscosity which can be expressed as below11 (8)

Its validity for the HDPE, used as the matrix, was examined by performing two different rheology experiments: (1) viscosity versus shear rate in a unidirectional shear mode and (2) complex viscosity versus frequency in an oscillatory shear mode. The very high wood content in the composites, under the study here, made it impossible to assess these composites under unidirectional shear mode.

sec.title: Generalized Maxwell model
sec.p:
The general equation for this model is given as follows11 (9) where Gk is the initial shear modulus and λk is the relaxation time of each Maxwell element. Figure 2 shows the mechanical analog of this model. The relaxation modulus is expressed as11 (10) Figure 2.
Mechanical analog of the generalized Maxwell model.11

All linear viscoelastic behavior is governed by the Boltzmann superposition principal, so it is possible to relate the response to any sufficiently small or slow deformation to the linear relaxation modulus. In the small amplitude oscillatory shear, if a generalized Maxwell model is used, it can be shown that G′(ω) and G′′(ω) are related to the relaxation modulus according to following equations11 (11) (12)

Applying the results obtained for G′(ω) and G′′(ω) in to the above equations, the relaxation modulus components of the composites can then be obtained. In the next step, by modeling the relaxation modulus, the optimum number of elements and their initial shear modulus and relaxation time were obtained for the composites.

sec.title: Measurement
sec.p: Dynamic oscillatory measurement has been established as the most reliable method for evaluating rheological properties of the filled polymers16. In the first part of this study, influence of wood flour content on the rheological properties of the composites was investigated versus angular frequency to obtain the data used for evaluating the flow behavior of the composites. Storage modulus (G′), loss modulus (G′′) and complex viscosity (η*) were thus measured.12

Measurements in dynamic shear mode were performed on a parallel plate UDS 200, ANTON – PAAR PHYSICA, rheometer under the strain-controlled condition within the linear viscoelastic region (LVR) of the materials. The plate diameter was 25 mm and the gap between the plates was maintained at 1mm. The strain amplitude was 5%, the set temperature was 170°C and the frequency sweep range was within 1 to 500 rad/s. Measurement below 1 rad/s was questionable due to possibility of wood degradation.12

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figures 3 and 4 shows storage modulus, loss modulus and complex viscosity as a function of frequency, respectively, for various wood contents. As it was predictable, the storage and loss modulus increase with increasing frequency, and the material exhibits a stiffening behavior against rapid loading. Complex viscosity decreases with increasing frequency showing that at a higher strain rate the material becomes less resistive (or less viscose). Figure 3.
Storage modulus (hollow marks) and loss modulus (filled marks) of wood - HDPE composites as a function of frequency, and at various wood contents.12 Figure 4.
Complex viscosity of wood - HDPE composites as a function of frequency, and at various wood contents.12

The most important finding in these graphs is that the changes are highly noticeable when the wood content increases from 60% to 70%. On the other hand, these changes are slight when the wood content increases from 40% to 50% and from 50% to 60%.

Via data processing, the shear stress values versus frequency were calculated. As the first step, Method 1 was employed to obtain the shear stress versus shear rate. After calculating shear rate according to equation (2), and following the procedure given for Method 1, the graphs of shear stress versus shear rate were depicted (Figure 5). Figure 5.
Shear stresses versus shear rate according to Method 1 and its exponential curve fits, for WPCs with various wood contents.

As mentioned in Methods 2 and 3, using complex and dynamic viscosities, respectively, for viscosity in the Newton’s equation, the shear stress was depicted versus shear rate (as shown in Figures 6 and 7). Figure 6.
Shear stresses versus shear rate according to Method 2 and its exponential curve fits, for WPCs with various wood contents. Figure 7.
Shear stresses versus shear rate according to Method 3 and its exponential curve fits, for WPCs with various wood contents.

Table 2 gives the parameters of power law equations of the composites for the three methods. As it can be seen, although the power law and consistency indexes in these methods are different with each other, the variation of shear stress versus shear rate nearly obeys the power law equation in all cases. Table 2.
Comparing the variables of the power law equation for method 1, 2 and 3
Content of wood (%) Method 1 Method 2 Method 3
m n m n m n
0 1000 0.79 700 0.79 600 0.75
40 3700 0.64 3700 0.65 3300 0.61
50 5000 0.53 5100 0.54 4500 0.50
60 8200 0.46 8400 0.47 7100 0.44
70 44,600 0.23 48,600 0.32 37,100 0.22
In Method 1, since the data were obtained directly from the rheometer instrument, they could be more reliable than those of the other methods thus these data can be used as the reference values.

The behavior of the viscosity, complex viscosity and dynamic viscosity versus shear rate are nearly the same but it is not allowed to use one instead of the others. According to the results, using dynamic viscosity for the composites with the high wood contents, the consistency and power law indexes values will converge to those of Method 1; however for the WPCs having low wood contents, using complex viscosity yields closer values to those of Method 1.

In another similar research with the same material, for the compcccccosite containing 40 wt% of wood, the value for power law index (n) was obtained as 0.87,17 which is noticeably high in comparison with those obtained by the other researches.18 But the results of power law index in the current study for WPCs with different wood contents are closer to the other reported values.18

As mentioned in the previous section, to examine the validity of Cox–Merz rule for the used HDPE in this study, two different rheological experiments were carried out, the results of which is shown in Figure 8. It can be seen that via increasing the shear rate or frequency, both viscosity and complex viscosity decrease slightly up to a frequency of 10 s−1. By increasing the frequency (or shear rate) higher than 10 s−1, the viscosity falls down significantly. Therefore, it can be concluded that at low frequencies (or small shear rates), the Cox–Merz rule is valid for the HDPE grade, used in this study. Figure 8.
Viscosity versus shear rate and complex viscosity versus frequency for HDPE.

Based on what mentioned previously, by decreasing the wood content in the wood-plastic composite, the complex viscosity will give better results in explaining the behavior of the composite. Moreover, it was seen that Cox–Merz rule will be valid in low frequencies for neat HDPE and so the viscosity and complex viscosity can be consider equal in this region. In other words, it can be concluded that for low content of wood in the composite and in low frequencies, the Cox–Merz rule can be applied for the WPCs.

Figure 9 shows the results of relaxation modulus measurement for the composites with various wood contents. As seen, the relaxation modulus increases with increasing the wood content and decreases with time increase. Another noticeable issue is that the relaxation modulus of the composites containing 40 and 50 wt% of wood content are nearly identical. Figure 9.
Relaxation modulus as a function of time for composites containing different contents of wood.
Moreover, as the relaxation modulus does not reveal any plateau region, it can be concluded that WPCs behave as polydisperse polymers.

The results of modeling the relaxation modulus with various wood contents are shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Maxwell parameters for the composites containing different contents of wood
Content of wood (%) No. of elements Gi λi Correlation
0 4 10,346 0.021 0.999
2132 0.057
793 0.150
357 0.400
40 3 72,817 0.021 0.999
10,642 0.092
8798 0.400
50 3 78,972 0.021 0.997
7427 0.080
12,095 0.308
60 2 91,602 0.021 0.989
46,480 0.400
70 3 520,130 0.021 0.995
48,235 0.092
254,940 0.400

It can be seen that the optimum number of Maxwell elements in the generalized Maxwell model is between 2 and 4 depending on the percentage of wood contents. It should be mentioned that although increasing the number of elements in the model will give finer approximation, but it will result in some negative values for Gi which is not acceptable.
According to the results from Table 3, it can be seen that the generalized Maxwell model gives a good approximation for the WPC.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Flow properties of HDPE-fine wood particle composites (40–70%) were investigated and the power law equation was used to predict the behavior of the materials. The wood component was provided from sanding process of particle-board manufacturing shop, with particle sizes below 50 µm. The results conclude the followings:
In frequency sweep measurement, significant changes were observed in storage modulus, loss modulus, and complex viscosity when adding wood content from 60% to 70%.
For the composites containing low wood contents, using complex viscosity will yield more reliable values for power law equation.
For the composites containing high contents of wood, using dynamic viscosity will yield more reliable values for power law equation.
In low frequencies or small shear rates (lower than 10 s−1), the Cox–Merz rule is valid for the HDPE which used as the polymeric matrix, and viscosity and complex viscosity can be considered equal.
For low content of wood and in low frequencies, the Cox–Merz rule can be applied for the WPC.
Generalized Maxwell model will give good approximation for the composites. Moreover, at the lower wood content, the approximation presents less error

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
